deliberation: The verse frames Israel’s exile in terms of divorce and debt-slavery. I distinguished between the marriage/divorce imagery (mother, bill of divorce, sending away) and the sale-to-creditors imagery (selling the people, being sold for sins). Both are standard prophetic metaphors for covenant rupture and exile, not literal legal transactions. I treated these as two distinct figurative complexes.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵי זֶה סֵפֶר כְּרִיתוּת אִמְּכֶם אֲשֶׁר שִׁלַּחְתִּיהָ ... וּבְפִשְׁעֵיכֶם שֻׁלְּחָה אִמְּכֶם
instances.english_text: Where is the bill of divorce of your mother whom I dismissed? … And your mother was dismissed for your crimes.
target: Zion/Israel’s covenant relationship with YHWH and its rupture (exile)
vehicle: A wife/mother being given a bill of divorce and sent away
ground: Legal termination of an intimate covenant bond because of offense
rupture and dismissal of a partner
shared concept of broken relationship due to fault
posture: Negative portrayal of Israel’s condition and guilt
instances.explanation: Israel/Zion is portrayed as a ‘mother’ divorced and sent away; the covenant rupture and exile are figuratively cast as a marital divorce, with ‘mother’ functioning metonymically for the people as a whole.

instances.hebrew_text: אוֹ מִי מִנּוֹשַׁי אֲשֶׁר־מָכַרְתִּי אֶתְכֶם לוֹ ... הֵן בַּעֲוֺנֹתֵיכֶם נִמְכַּרְתֶּם
instances.english_text: And which of My creditors was it to whom I sold you off? … You were sold off for your sins.
target: Israel’s loss of freedom and subjection in exile because of sin
vehicle: A debtor selling his children/servants to a creditor
ground: Being transferred into bondage as a consequence of obligation or wrongdoing
loss of freedom because of incurred liability
shared idea of punishment by enforced servitude
posture: Explanatory and accusatory stance toward Israel’s situation
instances.explanation: Israel’s exile is figured as being sold into slavery to a creditor; the ‘sale’ is not literal but a metaphor for entering bondage as a consequence of the people’s sins.

deliberation: I checked the rhetorical questions and the power imagery. ‘My hand too short to redeem’ is a known idiomatic metaphor for weakness. The description of YHWH’s rebuke drying up seas and turning rivers into desert is cosmic power imagery; it combines metaphor (his ‘rebuke’ acting as a physical force) with hyperbole about drying seas and rivers.

instances.english_text: Is my arm, then, too short to rescue?
target: YHWH’s ability to save and intervene
vehicle: A person’s shortened arm that cannot reach out to help
bodily incapacity to reach or grasp
ground: Inability to reach the object in need
limitations preventing successful rescue
shared notion of insufficient reach indicating weakness
posture: Denial of any limitation in God
instances.explanation: God’s saving power is figuratively questioned by picturing him as if he had a ‘short arm’ unable to reach; the idiom expresses supposed weakness, which the verse rejects.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן בְּגַעֲרָתִי אַחֲרִיב יָם אָשִׂים נְהָרוֹת מִדְבָּר
instances.english_text: With a mere rebuke I dry up the sea, and turn rivers into desert.
target: The overwhelming effectiveness of YHWH’s word of judgment or command
vehicle: A verbal rebuke that physically evaporates a sea and desolates rivers
speech acting as a catastrophic natural force
ground: Immediate and irresistible effects proceeding from a single authoritative word
capacity to overturn natural orders
shared idea of overwhelming efficacy
instances.explanation: God’s ‘rebuke’ is portrayed as if it directly dries seas and turns rivers into desert; this hyperbolic metaphor emphasizes the irresistible and cosmic scope of his power.

deliberation: The verse uses clothing language for the heavens. This is not literal; the skies do not wear garments. The darkening of the heavens is expressed by metaphor and personification, with sackcloth evoking mourning.

instances.hebrew_text: אַלבִּישׁ שָׁמַיִם קַדְרוּת וְשַׂק אָשִׂים כְּסוּתָם
instances.english_text: I clothe the skies in blackness and make their raiment sackcloth.
target: Cosmic gloom and judgment signaled by darkened heavens
state of the sky as omen of judgment
vehicle: A person dressed in black sackcloth for mourning
ground: External appearance signaling grief and calamity
dark, rough garments indicating mourning and humiliation
shared visual sign of sorrow and judgment
instances.explanation: The heavens are personified as if they were clothed in black sackcloth, a human mourning garment, to picture cosmic mourning and judgment.

deliberation: I considered whether the ‘tongue of those who are taught’ and the ‘awakening of the ear’ are literal. Both use body parts to stand for communicative and receptive capacities. ‘Tongue’ is a synecdoche/metonymy for speech ability; ‘awakening the ear’ is a metaphor for making the servant attentive, with ‘ear’ as metonymy for obedience.

instances.english_text: My Sovereign GOD gave me a skilled tongue (a tongue of disciples).
target: The servant’s God-given ability to speak fitting, instructive words
vehicle: The ‘tongue’ as the physical organ of speech belonging to learners/disciples
ground: The tongue as the instrument by which speech occurs
association of the organ with its communicative function
part–whole relation (synecdoche)
instances.explanation: ‘Tongue’ stands metonymically/synecdochically for the capacity and gift of speech shaped by divine instruction (‘of those who are taught’).

instances.hebrew_text: יָעִיר בַּבֹּקֶר בַּבֹּקֶר יָעִיר לִי אֹזֶן לִשְׁמֹעַ כַּלִּמּוּדִים
instances.english_text: Morning by morning He rouses me, rousing my ear to give heed like disciples.
target: The servant’s growing receptivity and obedience to God’s instruction
vehicle: An ear being awakened from sleep so that it can hear
arousing a bodily organ to active function
ground: Transition from unresponsiveness to alert attentiveness
becoming ready and able to receive messages
shared idea of being ‘woken up’ to hear/obey
instances.explanation: God is said to ‘awaken the ear’—a metaphor for making the servant attentive and obedient, with ‘ear’ functioning metonymically for the whole listening-and-obeying person.

deliberation: The central image is God ‘opening the ear’. This is not anatomical surgery but an idiomatic metaphor for making someone willing and obedient. The ‘ear’ again stands synecdochically for attentive obedience.

instances.english_text: My Sovereign GOD opened my ears.
target: The servant’s readiness to hear and obey God’s word
vehicle: An ear being opened so that sound can enter
removing a blockage from a bodily organ
ground: Transition from closed/unresponsive to open/receptive
enabling communication to be received
shared concept of accessibility to messages
posture: Affirmation of obedient response to God
instances.explanation: ‘Opening the ear’ is a stock idiom for making someone receptive and obedient to instruction; ‘ear’ stands metonymically for the person’s obedient hearing.

deliberation: The verse describes physical abuse: back to floggers, cheeks to hair-pluckers, face not hidden from insult and spitting. These read as straightforward descriptions of suffering without clear metaphor, simile, or other figurative devices beyond normal concrete language. While ‘back’ and ‘cheeks’ could be taken as synecdoches for the whole person, in this context they are the literal body parts being attacked, so I did not count them as distinct figurative expressions.

The key figurative element is ‘I have set my face like flint’—an explicit simile and idiomatic expression for unyielding resolve. Other clauses (‘will help me’, ‘I shall not be shamed’) are straightforward.

instances.english_text: Therefore I have set my face like flint.
target: The servant’s steadfast, unflinching determination in the face of opposition
vehicle: Flint, a very hard stone that does not easily break or change shape
ground: Hardness, resistance to pressure, and inability to be easily altered
steadfastness despite blows
shared quality of unyielding firmness
posture: Strongly positive valuation of determined obedience
instances.explanation: The servant’s resolve is compared to ‘flint’ using a simile; this idiomatic metaphor conveys hardness and unyielding determination not to be turned aside by shame or opposition.

deliberation: The verse is saturated with legal/courtroom language (‘my Vindicator,’ ‘contend,’ ‘stand up together,’ ‘my opponent,’ ‘approach me’). The conflict is framed as a lawsuit before a judge; God is described as one who justifies. I treat the legal-litigational framing as a single extended metaphor for vindication in the divine court.

instances.hebrew_text: קָרוֹב מַצְדִּיקִי מִי־יָרִיב אִתִּי נַעַמְדָה יָּחַד מִי־בַעַל מִשְׁפָּטִי יִגַּשׁ אֵלָי
instances.english_text: My Vindicator is at hand—Who dares contend with me? Let us stand up together! Who would be my opponent? Let them approach me!
target: The servant’s opposition and ultimate vindication before God
vehicle: A law-court setting with a justifier, litigants, an opponent, and formal contention
ground: Issues being decided by an authoritative judgment, with one party declared in the right
formal confrontation leading to a verdict
shared concept of adjudicated vindication
posture: Confident assertion of innocence and trust in divine justification
instances.explanation: The servant’s situation is metaphorically cast as a lawsuit: God is the ‘vindicator’ (one who justifies), and opponents are imagined as courtroom adversaries who may ‘approach’ to contend.

deliberation: After affirming God’s help, the verse depicts opponents as transient: they ‘will all wear out like a garment’ and ‘the moth shall consume them’. These are two related but distinct images: a simile likening them to a wearing-out garment, and a metaphor picturing them as being eaten by moths.

instances.english_text: They shall all wear out like a garment.
target: The servant’s adversaries and their eventual demise or insignificance
vehicle: A garment that gradually decays and wears out with use
ground: Gradual decay and loss of usefulness over time
inevitable deterioration and disappearance
shared notion of transience and perishability
posture: Dismissive of the enemies’ lasting power
reassuring the servant of their impermanence
instances.explanation: Opponents are compared via simile to a garment that wears out, highlighting their temporary and fragile status.

target: The same adversaries and their destruction
vehicle: A moth eating through fabric until it is destroyed
ground: Silent, gradual, often unnoticed destruction from within
frailty before small agents of decay
shared sense of vulnerability and eventual ruin
posture: Further diminishes the perceived solidity of the enemies
instances.explanation: By picturing the enemies as if they were garments eaten by moths, the metaphor stresses how fragile and easily undone they are before God’s judgment.

deliberation: Two main figures appear. ‘Walking in darkness and having no light’ is a metaphor for a believer’s experience of distress/confusion. ‘Trust in the name of YHWH’ uses ‘name’ metonymically for God’s character and reliable self-revelation.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר הָלַךְ חֲשֵׁכִים וְאֵין נֹגַהּ לוֹ
instances.english_text: Though walking in darkness and having no light.
target: The situation of a God-fearing person who lacks clarity, comfort, or visible help
vehicle: A person physically walking in the dark without any light
ground: Lack of visibility, guidance, and security; vulnerability to missteps
inability to see the way ahead
shared idea of confusion and danger
posture: Empathetic acknowledgment of the believer’s hard condition
instances.explanation: The inner and outer hardships of the God-fearing person are portrayed as ‘walking in darkness with no light’, a metaphor for confusion and vulnerability without visible guidance.

instances.english_text: Let them trust in the name of GOD.
target: YHWH himself as trustworthy, and his revealed character and promises
vehicle: designation standing for the person and reputation
ground: A name represents and evokes the person’s character, authority, and reliability
invoking the name is functionally relying on the person
shared metonymic link between name and bearer
posture: Encouragement of faith in God’s dependable character
instances.explanation: ‘Name’ stands metonymically for YHWH himself—his character, presence, and promises—so trusting in his ‘name’ means relying on him.

deliberation: The whole verse uses fire imagery for self-made guidance or schemes: kindling fire, girding with sparks, walking in the light of one’s own fire. This is metaphorical for self-reliant, rebellious reliance on human plans and also carries ironic force, since the invited ‘walking’ in their fire leads to lying down in torment. I treated this cluster as one extended metaphor with ironic posture.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן כֻּלְּכֶם קֹדְחֵי אֵשׁ מְאַזְּרֵי זִיקוֹת לְכוּ בְּאוּר אֶשְׁכֶם וּבְזִיקוֹת בִּעַרְתֶּם ... לְמַעֲצֵבָה תִּשְׁכָּבוּן
instances.english_text: But you are all kindlers of fire, girding on firebrands. Walk by the blaze of your fire, by the brands that you have lit! … You shall lie down in pain.
target: The people’s self-made schemes, false sources of guidance, and rebellious self-reliance, and the misery they reap
human counsel and autonomy opposed to God
vehicle: Kindling a fire, surrounding oneself with sparks, and walking in the light of that self-made fire
ground: Depending on one’s own manufactured ‘light’ instead of true external light; temporary, dangerous illumination that ends in harm
initiative that seems helpful but leads to burning and exhaustion
shared idea that self-generated guidance can be deceptive and destructive
posture: Ironically invites them to pursue their path to expose its folly, culminating in announced pain
instances.explanation: Those who reject trusting God are depicted as people who light their own fire and walk in its blaze—an ironic metaphor for self-reliant schemes that will end in ‘lying down in pain’. The language functions as both metaphor and biting irony.
